makers.displaydate: 1902–1984; born San Francisco, CA; died Monterey, CA; active San Francisco, CA and Carmel-by-the-Sea, CA
makers.displaymaker: Ansel Adams, 1902–1984; born San Francisco, CA; died Monterey, CA; active San Francisco, CA and Carmel-by-the-Sea, CA

texts.textentryhtml: Famed for his landscape photographs of the western United States, Adams—like many American artists in the 1930s—also turned his attention to homegrown traditions of craft and artistry that were then disappearing in the face of rapid modernization. This photograph of a delicately carved nineteenth-century tombstone recalls the many images Adams took in Mount Laurel Cemetery in his native San Francisco. By opposing the rounded, arched form of the tombstone and the sharp angles of the rough-hewn stones behind it, Adams transforms sentimental and antiquated subject matter into a study of space, light, and geometry—a perfect expression of modernist art’s ideals.

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1971," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University, 31 no. 1 (1972): p. 20-32.
bibliography.citation:
"Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1971," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University, 31 no. 1 (1972): p. 20-32.
